newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft warns Office 97 sales could slow.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft warns Office 97 sales could slow.

text.p: Microsoft Corp Chief Financial Officer Mike Brown on Tuesday said the company's Office 97 software package had been a "sizzling success," but he warned of saturation in the category and tough comparisons next year.

Brown, speaking to investors at a conference sponsored by the Ragen MacKenzie brokerage, reiterated that Microsoft had sold about 5.0 million copies of the Office software bundle, which was launched in January.
"As you look forward ... you have to be a little more cautious," he said. "I think it will be likely to continue to grow, but it's the slowest growing part of our revenue pie."
During the past 12 months, Office and other applications generated $4.0 billion in revenues, or about 43 percent of Microsoft's total, Brown said.
He said the BackOffice suite of server products, tailored for Microsoft's Windows NT operating system, generated $1.8 billion and was the fastest-growing component.

Sales of Microsoft's Windows operating systems, generally installed on new computers, accounted for $2.8 billion, while the remaining $800 million came from other categories, including hardware and interactive media.

Brown said he expected a "substantial" increase in spending on research and development in the fiscal year that begins July 1 over the estimated $2.1 billion this year, but he declined to be specific.

And Brown indicated that the so-called Windows 97 operating system update, now expected to be released in the second half of fiscal 1998, would not have a significant impact on Microsoft's revenue growth.
Based on early customer feedback, the product would largely be a "technical" upgrade, and Microsoft did not plan to impose a price increase over Windows 95, he said.
